text:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion,

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

Since the creation of digital devices and its implementation, I believe many have been wary to have people depend on screens, instead of in person interactions.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

Since the creation of digital devices and its implementation, I believe many have been wary to have people depend on screens, instead of in person interactions. 

I think the worry is that we are losing our ability to communicate with each other, and that we are losing our ability to be social.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

Since the creation of digital devices and its implementation, I believe many have been wary to have people depend on screens, instead of in person interactions. I think the worry is that we are losing our ability to communicate with each other, and that we are losing our ability to be social. This however is not a new or recent worry, in fact many believed the same with the implementation of writing, and the widespread use and access of literature. Back then, people worried that book writing and reading would cause humans as a whole to lose the ability to interact with one another, and they feared it would lead to the deterioration of society over time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

Since the creation of digital devices and its implementation, I believe many have been wary to have people depend on screens, instead of in person interactions. I think the worry is that we are losing our ability to communicate with each other, and that we are losing our ability to be social. This however is not a new or recent worry, in fact many believed the same with the implementation of writing, and the widespread use and access of literature. Back then, people worried that book writing and reading would cause humans as a whole to lose the ability to interact with one another, and they feared it would lead to the deterioration of society over time. But as we know, this was not the case. I think the worries and concerns regarding screen use are similar and applicable to the ones that were made in the past towards written literature. In fact, I believe that even if screen use becomes more refined and widespread, there will still be benefits and values for people to continue to interact in person and without the use of screens, and that technology like smartphones will be better integrated and moderated in the lives of people.

I think the worry is that we are losing our ability to communicate with each other, and that we are losing our ability to be social. This however is not a new or recent worry, in fact many believed the same with the implementation of writing, and the widespread use and access of literature. Back then, people worried that book writing and reading would cause humans as a whole to lose the ability to interact with one another, and they feared it would lead to the deterioration of society over time. But as we know, this was not the case. I think the worries and concerns regarding screen use are similar and applicable to the ones that were made in the past towards written literature. In fact, I believe that even if screen use becomes more refined and widespread, there will still be benefits and values for people to continue to interact in person and without the use of screens, and that technology like smartphones will be better integrated and moderated in the lives of people.



I believe that the benefits of screen use far outweigh the negatives.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

This however is not a new or recent worry, in fact many believed the same with the implementation of writing, and the widespread use and access of literature. Back then, people worried that book writing and reading would cause humans as a whole to lose the ability to interact with one another, and they feared it would lead to the deterioration of society over time. But as we know, this was not the case. I think the worries and concerns regarding screen use are similar and applicable to the ones that were made in the past towards written literature. In fact, I believe that even if screen use becomes more refined and widespread, there will still be benefits and values for people to continue to interact in person and without the use of screens, and that technology like smartphones will be better integrated and moderated in the lives of people.

I believe that the benefits of screen use far outweigh the negatives. Even considering that during the pandemic that the screen use of people has notably increased, for most due to remote work and others for their safety and to limit the spread of the virus, screen use will not replace many of the interactions people hold for the time being. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

Since the creation of digital devices and its implementation, I believe many have been wary to have people depend on screens, instead of in person interactions. I think the worry is that we are losing our ability to communicate with each other, and that we are losing our ability to be social. This however is not a new or recent worry, in fact many believed the same with the implementation of writing, and the widespread use and access of literature. Back then, people worried that book writing and reading would cause humans as a whole to lose the ability to interact with one another, and they feared it would lead to the deterioration of society over time. But as we know, this was not the case. I think the worries and concerns regarding screen use are similar and applicable to the ones that were made in the past towards written literature. In fact, I believe that even if screen use becomes more refined and widespread, there will still be benefits and values for people to continue to interact in person and without the use of screens, and that technology like smartphones will be better integrated and moderated in the lives of people.

I believe that the benefits of screen use far outweigh the negatives. Even considering that during the pandemic that the screen use of people has notably increased, for most due to remote work and others for their safety and to limit the spread of the virus, screen use will not replace many of the interactions people hold for the time being. Remote work and similar usages of screen use during the pandemic was a means to make due during the pandemic, and for many jobs and workers, it was not a adequate replacement for them. For example retail workers, would still work as well as other essential workers. I think beyond them , there are many other people that would not be able to work remotely, and would still need to go into the office or other places of work.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

Since the creation of digital devices and its implementation, I believe many have been wary to have people depend on screens, instead of in person interactions. I think the worry is that we are losing our ability to communicate with each other, and that we are losing our ability to be social. This however is not a new or recent worry, in fact many believed the same with the implementation of writing, and the widespread use and access of literature. Back then, people worried that book writing and reading would cause humans as a whole to lose the ability to interact with one another, and they feared it would lead to the deterioration of society over time. But as we know, this was not the case. I think the worries and concerns regarding screen use are similar and applicable to the ones that were made in the past towards written literature. In fact, I believe that even if screen use becomes more refined and widespread, there will still be benefits and values for people to continue to interact in person and without the use of screens, and that technology like smartphones will be better integrated and moderated in the lives of people.

I believe that the benefits of screen use far outweigh the negatives. Even considering that during the pandemic that the screen use of people has notably increased, for most due to remote work and others for their safety and to limit the spread of the virus, screen use will not replace many of the interactions people hold for the time being. Remote work and similar usages of screen use during the pandemic was a means to make due during the pandemic, and for many jobs and workers, it was not a adequate replacement for them. For example retail workers, would still work as well as other essential workers. I think beyond them , there are many other people that would not be able to work remotely out of both preference and necessity, and would still need to go into the office or other places of work. For them, it is more engaging to work in person with colleagues, and their fellow co-workers. Still, there are people who benefit from the remote work option, and after the pandemic ends will continue to do so. For that reason, I don't think that is reasonable to worry about the increase in usage and dependency of screen use from the pandemic, as when the pandemic subsides, it is likely that many will reduce their usage out of necessity, and for work, school, and social interactions. The benefits of screen use ought to be embraced during the pandemic and afterwards, for they allow people to stay connected when they are unable to, out of safety or for other personal reasons. Screen use will not cause most to depend on it solely in their lives, like written work and literature, many will learn over time to moderate it, and find a balance in their life regarding its usage to maximize its benefits.
